articles.headline: F.B.I., Pushing to Stop Domestic Terrorists, Grapples With Limits on Its Power
articles.snippet: A debate has emerged over whether federal law enforcement has enough tools to fight racially motivated mass shootings and other attacks.
articles.abstract: A debate has emerged over whether federal law enforcement has enough tools to fight racially motivated mass shootings and other attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERETT, Wash. — Dakota Reed’s mind brimmed with thoughts of mass murder. In November, he wrote on Facebook, “I am shooting for 30 Jews.”

articles.headline: As Trump Dangles Post-Brexit Trade Deal, Some Britons See Opportunism
articles.snippet: The prospect of a Britain overly dependent on the United States divided politicians and added to the grievances of anti-Trump protesters in London.
articles.abstract: The prospect of a Britain overly dependent on the United States divided politicians and added to the grievances of anti-Trump protesters in London.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Trump on Tuesday urged Britain to forge ahead with plans to quit the European Union, dangling the prospect of a “phenomenal” trade deal with the United States as the British grapple with a polarizing political crisis.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Parkland Officer Who Stayed Outside During Shooting Faces Criminal Charges
articles.snippet: Scot Peterson, a former Broward County sheriff’s deputy, faces charges of neglect of a child, culpable negligence and perjury, the authorities said.
articles.abstract: Scot Peterson, a former Broward County sheriff’s deputy, faces charges of neglect of a child, culpable negligence and perjury, the authorities said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — As bullets ricocheted and bodies fell in the hallways and classrooms at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School last year, Deputy Scot Peterson was outside the building. Instead of storming in after the 19-year-old gunman, he retreated to a position of safety.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Senate Republicans Warn White House Against Mexico Tariffs
articles.snippet: In a contentious meeting at the Capitol, Senate Republicans told senior White House officials that they are prepared to resist tariffs on Mexico if President Trump pushes forward.
articles.abstract: In a contentious meeting at the Capitol, Senate Republicans told senior White House officials that they are prepared to resist tariffs on Mexico if President Trump pushes forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican senators sent the White House a sharp message on Tuesday, warning that they were almost uniformly opposed to President Trump’s plans to impose tariffs on Mexican imports, just hours after the president said lawmakers would be “foolish” to try to stop him.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Modern Monetary Theory’s Reluctant Poster Child: Japan
articles.snippet: Despite its huge debt, the country remains an economic powerhouse. Some say it provides a model for the United States, but its leaders disavow the idea.
articles.abstract: Despite its huge debt, the country remains an economic powerhouse. Some say it provides a model for the United States, but its leaders disavow the idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Spend big and never mind the deficit. That’s what proponents of modern monetary theory, the unorthodox set of economic ideas that has inspired politicians like Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, see as the winning formula for American prosperity.

articles.headline: Trump’s Split-Screen Persona on Blaring Display in U.K. Visit
articles.snippet: Over his three-day trip, the president embraced regal respectability on one side, and settling scores on the other.
articles.abstract: Over his three-day trip, the president embraced regal respectability on one side, and settling scores on the other.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — He quoted Roosevelt and gently greeted frail veterans at a D-Day commemoration, hours after proclaiming Bette Midler a “psycho” and Chuck Schumer a “creep.” He exalted soldiers’ bravery while dismissing his avoidance of service in Vietnam, calling it a country “nobody heard of.” He toasted Britain’s queen at a Buckingham Palace banquet, after calling London’s mayor a loser.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Trump Says No Deal With Mexico Is Reached as Border Arrests Surge
articles.snippet: President Trump said not enough progress was made in meetings between the Mexican and U.S. governments but that talks would resume on Thursday.
articles.abstract: President Trump said not enough progress was made in meetings between the Mexican and U.S. governments but that talks would resume on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated June 6, 2019: After this story was published, officials from Customs and Border Protection said on Thursday that illegal border crossings have risen to a 13-year high, not a seven-year high as they had reported earlier.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: YouTube to Remove Thousands of Videos Pushing Extreme Views
articles.snippet: The decision by YouTube, which is owned by Google, is the latest action by a Silicon Valley company to stem the spread of hate speech and disinformation on their sites.
articles.abstract: The decision by YouTube, which is owned by Google, is the latest action by a Silicon Valley company to stem the spread of hate speech and disinformation on their sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: YouTube announced plans on Wednesday to remove thousands of videos and channels that advocate neo-Nazism, white supremacy and other bigoted ideologies in an attempt to clean up extremism and hate speech on its popular service.
articles.byline: By Kevin Roose and Kate Conger
